title: Before 1 May 2020, will China reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans?
preds: Bumping up to 91%.  Recent articles such as the Foreign Policy article on 14 Feb below state that China "cut" tariffs on soybeans, but others like the CNBC via Reuters and FX Street on 17 and 18 Feb reported that China is granting tariff exemptions on soybeans.  There seems to be some confusion on the exact status of the tariffs.  If anyone is seeing anything different, let me know. https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/02/14/china-united-states-trade-deal-commitments-coronavirus-trump-energy-huawei/  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/18/us-china-trade-beijing-to-accept-tariff-exemption-requests-on-us-imports.html https://www.fxstreet.com/news/china-will-proceed-with-process-of-tariff-exemptions-on-696-goods-imported-from-the-us-202002180416
China is too shrewd to do this before the election.  I think they hold the line on this.

China will be forced to concede in the trade war due to the impact of Coronavirus. However, it is still possible that nationalistic pride, muscle flexing, and China’s ability to insularise will triumph over economic necessity. The added potential of US soybeans being more available than typically globally due to climate change may make it more than economic necessity too.  https://phys.org/news/2019-07-climate-corn-soybeans-upper-midwest.html

This is my initial forecast for this question.  Starting at 90% due to the two articles below that others have cited. I am unsure if China has fully removed the soybean tariff as stated in the Foreign Policy link below or has agreed that they will do it. https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/02/14/china-united-states-trade-deal-commitments-coronavirus-trump-energy-huawei/
https://www.agriculture.com/markets/newswire/grains-soybeans-firm-turning-up-on-prospects-for-chinese-export-demand

The tariff cut on soybeans has taken effect as of yesterday: "The phase one U.S.-China trade deal enters into force...United States cutting tariffs on $120 billion of Chinese goods in half and China reciprocating on $75 billion of U.S. goods, including cars, crude oil, and soybeans [1]. [1] https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/02/14/china-united-states-trade-deal-commitments-coronavirus-trump-energy-huawei/
Increasing estimate due to the possibility that impending soybean tariff changes may not be solely enacted through exemptions and waivers.

Staying at 90%, but wanted to share a great source: https://www.agriculture.com/markets/newswire/grains-soybeans-firm-turning-up-on-prospects-for-chinese-export-demand BLUF: Phase 1 of the China trade deal should go into effect today (14 Feb), and accordingly, the market is adjusting from short (i.e. betting the prices will drop) positions. This further indicates the soybean tariff will be lifted today, and not (at least as I understand it) through waivers or exemptions.

Updating (raising) my forecast. Found a different source (https://kiwaradio.com/ag-news/china-to-cut-tariffs-on-u-s-imports-on-february-14th/) that clarifies China's plan is in fact to cut tariffs on 14 Feb. That it is indeed a cut in tariffs means that this meets this question's criteria. I expect this question to close out on 14 Feb when China puts these changes in place. With this source clarifying the situation, increasing the odds of this happening by 30% from previous assessment. Very small probability that China changes its mind in the next 24 hrs.
Providing a lower forecast than team consensus and crowd forecast as waivers were used to reduce tariffs on 6 February vice an actual reduction.

The 6 Feb 2020 news that China cut tariffs from 30% to 27.5% appears to be through tariff waivers (https://www.agweb.com/article/soybeans-nudge-higher-after-china-makes-small-tariff-cut), so per the instructions above, this question is not yet resolved. INCREASING the odds that China will actually make permanent cuts is the fact that the US and China are progressing with a multi-phase trade deal where both sides are indicating willingness to compromise; also, Brazil's current bumper crop means that Brazil beans are going to be cheaper, so it may actually cost China nothing to lower tariffs on US products because they're not competitive anyway yet it will show a measure of goodwill in the trade war. Thus, it's more likely than not China will take advantage of this situation and permanently reduce the July 2018 soybean tariffs (though probably not by much).

According to Bloomberg.com  on Feb 6th (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-06/china-to-halve-tariffs-on-75-billion-u-s-goods-from-feb-14),  January 15th deal cuts tariffs on soybeans from 30% to 27.5%.  Cuts are effective on Feb 14th.  Keeping a 5% margin in case Coronavirus causes a delay, however even if it does I don't see it extending for 2.5 months.
I believe the coronavirus will so inpact Ch8na that they will need the imports.

How Chinese tariffs on U.S. imports will stand after February 14 cuts.
\
Aizhu, Xu, Patton, Daly, Singh and Gu (2020). Feb.6, stated that:
\
BEIJING/SINGAPORE (Reuters) - China is preparing to halve the extra tariffs on U.S goods that went into effect last September, including on crude oil, soybeans, pork and beef (Para. 1).
\
It will see total tariffs on soybeans fall to 27.5% from 30%, total duties on pork drop to 55% from 60% and those on beef do down to 30% from 35%. Tariffs for U.S. crude oil, which was first targeted in September, will be reduced to 2.5% from 5% (Para. 4).
\
SOYBEANS
The Chinese government has given tariff exemptions to some U.S. soybean imports. In 2019, China brought in 16.94 million tonnes of U.S. soybeans, edging up from 16.6 million tonnes in 2018, when shipments nearly halved from the previous year due to the trade dispute. The Chinese government has given tariff exemptions to some U.S. soybean imports.
\
Reference

China's economic growth already began to slow in 2019. SARS, which was less infectious but more lethal, resulted in more than a 1% reduction in GDP. nCoV, though less lethal, appears to be much more infectious and will likely result in overall more deaths. China will likely be unable to contain the nCoV outbreak. The regional travel bans affect not only ordinary citizens but also livestock & poultry farmers. These farmers can neither longer bring their animals to market nor can they buy feed to keep them alive. If this continues, China's stability may be threatened by rural unrest. By reducing or eliminating tariffs on US soybeans, China will appear to be help farmers.
Reduced probability - China has a much more urgent crisis (corona virus outbreak) to deal with right now and in the near future.

Absorbing the question more closely and rereading my prior rationale  - together they make me feel I did only a cursory consideration of the question.
In particular, exemptions and waivers will not count towards this question.
And waivers of tariffs seemed central to me to how the Chinese government will bring in soybeans from the US without breaking those importers' P&L.
Given US tariffs are staying in place through the 2020 election, and this matter having an established tit-for-tat methodology - I see nothing that compels China to feel the need to actually reduce tariffs. And an early reduction of tariff broadcasts, without near-certain reciprocity by the US, would, to me, Chinese bargaining weakness.
So a low single-digit possibility seems appropriate.

A reduction or removal of US (yellow) soybeans is highly unlikely as there were no substantive arrangements nor any indication that tariffs would be rolled back in phase 1 of the US-China trade deal. Separately, Brazil has emerged as significant exporter of soybeans to China - helping offset the need for the reduction or removal of tariffs, at least in the short-term. Moreover, as Brazilian soybean crops are harvested from January through May, it is more likely that a reduction in tariffs would occur in the later half of 2020.  During the two-year trade war, China has imported a large amounts of soybeans for strategic reserves - one that the Chinese state claimed was not reliant on American imports. However, adverse crop growing conditions in Brazil would change this view.
China is not going to move

The phase 1 trade deal between the US and China makes no provisions for the rolling back of the tariffs imposed by the US on Chinese products, or the retaliatory tariffs imposed by China, including those on yellow soybeans.  As China has new soybean contracts with Brazil there is little supply side rationale for the Chinese to remove tariffs imposed in retaliation for the US tariffs.  The US President will not cave on the tariff issue at this point as doing so would be to loose the trade war we claimed would be so easy to win.

Phase 1 agreement does not mention reduction and removal of tariffs. You can download and read the full document here (1).  It is unlikely more trade agreements will happen before the election. Reducing the probability. (1)  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/15/trump-and-china-sign-phase-one-trade-agreement.html

Agricultural products are an important part of the Phase 1 trade deal, yet the details do not direct China to alter their tariff structure. While on the long list of agricultural goods that may be part of basket of purchases that fulfills Chinese commitments, only wheat, rice, and corn are subject to a specific tariff quota commitment. https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/files/agreements/phase%20one%20agreement/Economic_And_Trade_Agreement_Between_The_United_States_And_China_Text.pdf  While I’m uncertain about the CCP’s incentives to adjust as opposed to waive tariffs, my assumption is that they would choose a less permanent approach (waivers or exemptions) to retain perceived leverage, consistent with their actions to date. China’s interim efforts to obtain soybeans from other parties may also decrease their use of soybeans to address their agricultural commitment under Phase 1. Soybeans are an important component of any leverage China has in these negotiations for both their political and economic impact, both because of their role in key states in the U.S. farm economy, and because China typically consumes just under one-third of the global soybean crop and accounts for about two-thirds of the world’s trade in soybeans.  http://www.startribune.com/soybean-prices-won-t-recover-in-2020-regardless-of-china-trade-talks-economist/566129121/ Soybeans were one of China’s first retaliatory targets, along with aluminum, airplanes, cars, and pork, and it appears the Phase 1 deal leaves China discretion in continuing its approach to exemptions and waivers, and does not directly address tariffs on these items. Given the length and intensity of negotiations over Phase 1, and the U.S. President's statements about his timeline for a further deal and the specific contentious issues on the table, my expectations are low for a deal with more comprehensive agreement compelling fully unwinding the tariffs and retaliatory tariffs imposed in 2018 before May 2020. That said, there remains a possibility China will choose to lower tariffs as opposed to use waivers to address its Phase 1 deal commitments.

@Si-Fi's excellent rationale, and especially the observation that the US soy growing season ended in November, so there's no soy supply at stake until after May 2020 anyway, leads me to drop my estimate even further.

While there is not direct language referring to specific tariffs on Soybean stated, the contractual obligation to purchase Soybean exists specifically outlines in Section 6 Agriculture 9 Oilseeds HS Code Product Description, 1201 Soybeans, whether or not broken (PDF Pg.69) page 6-17 of the Agreement.  Increases in U.S. Exports to China over 2 Years pg. 6-5 underscores the argument, China’s Soybean Tariffs will have to remain at the Lowered December 2019 and January 2020 rate of 3%.  China in the past, for shipments in October thru December waived or reduced back to 3% to fulfill the specific needs of China at that Time.  The Agreement specifically states the dates, under Article 6.2: Trade Opportunities as, 1 During the two-year period from January 1, 2020 through December 31, 2021. Any rate reduction within this two-year period will exists to fulfill contractional oblations. Whereby, China must continue the lower or use the original 3% rate charges all other countries on Soybeans to the US offer a completive price. On Soybean to fulfill or attempt to fill their end of the above aforementioned Phase One agreement., While there may exists, some who demand a written agreement on the tariffs, there exists no written agreement between the US and China on the original 3%. The country of origin initiates the percentage of tariffs to fit their needs. The probability does not state a written agreement or a finalized trade agreement is needed. 
Stating temporary waivers or exemptions will not count, at the formation of this question were on a month to month foundation. 
Reduction on Soybean during the two-year period from January 1, 2020 through December 31, 2021 exists in accordance with the Phase One, time-frame. Moving them to specified time frame outlined in the agreement thus are not temporary.  China’s 2019 exemptions and waivers were intended to implement this Chapter, of the Agreement. Inasmuch as without incentive to the US for Trade talks the agreement would not have been signed. Without a continued reduction China just committed to buy products at a 33% premium forced on Chinese Businesses, Farmers and Consumers. That is just not what China’s Trade Agreements with the US is about.   \ Tang (2019) December 15, states that: China said on Sunday it will not impose new tariffs on imports of American products, but added that the ongoing negotiations between the two countries must proceed on the basis of equality and respect (Para. 1). The announcement came after an interim agreement was reached on Friday to prevent a further escalation of the trade war, which has been running since July 2018.
Beijing had threatened to introduce tariffs of 5 and 10 per cent on selected US goods at noon on Sunday, but that move had been halted, the Customs Tariff Commission of the State Council said in an online statement. It also said that US cars and car parts would continue to be exempted from existing duties.
China hoped it could continue to “work with the US on the basis of equality and mutual respect to address the concerns of both parties and promote the steady development of the China-US trade relations”, it said.
During the negotiations for a “phase one” deal, Beijing repeatedly called for the suspension of any tariff increases by the US on Chinese products and for existing duties to be lifted.
After weeks of debate and deliberation, Washington on Friday halted its plan to introduce fresh tariffs on the remaining US$100 billion worth of Chinese goods that were exempt from the punitive action, and said it would halve its existing duties on about US$120 billion of Chinese imports to 7.5 per cent.
However, a 25 per cent tariff on about US$250 billion worth of Chinese goods would remain in place, it said. Besides the removal of tariffs, the US said the “historic and enforceable” phase one deal would require China to make structural and other changes to its economic and trade regime in the areas of intellectual property, technology transfer, agriculture, financial services, and currency and foreign exchange.
“The phase one agreement also includes a commitment by China that it will make substantial additional purchases of US goods and services in the coming years,” the trade representative’s office said (Para. 1-9).
\
Reference
\
Tang, F. (2019). Trade war China halts introduction of new tariffs on US goods. The South China Morning Post. Economy. China Economy. December 15, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3042160/trade-war-china-halts-introduction-new-tariffs-us-goods \
Speaking in the South China Morning Post, Per Phase One Trade Agreement, Xin (2019) September 13, stated that: China has announced that it will exclude imports of U.S. soybeans, pork and other farm goods from additional trade war tariffs, opening the door for significant purchases of agricultural products (Para. 1).
The official Xinhua News Agency reported on Friday that China's National Development and Reform Commission and the Ministry of Commerce made the exemption in response to the U.S.’ decision of postpone an increase in the tariff rate on $250 billion of Chinese goods from October 1 to October 15. It comes after U.S. President Donald Trump spoke on Thursday of the possibility of an “interim trade deal” over the coming weeks. Beijing will allow Chinese businesses to purchase a “certain amount of farm products such as soybeans and pork” from the United States, according to the Xinhua report. “China’s market is big enough and there’s great potential to import high-quality U.S. farm products.” It added that Chinese authorities hoped that “the U.S. will honor its word and fulfil its promises to create favorable conditions for cooperation for the two countries in the agriculture sector”. Hua Changchun, an economist at Guotai Junan Securities, a brokerage, said Beijing's move has increased the likelihood of a narrow trade deal (Para. 1-6). “But it's a small deal,” Hua said. “It means that there would be no escalation of tariffs as China has agreed to make more purchases. It could provide a certain level of comfort to U.S. farmers and give Trump something to brag about.” It marks the latest in series of rapid-fire developments this week that suggest a concerted effort by China to push for a partial, or interim, trade deal (Para 1-7). China has also imposed 30 per cent in tariffs on yellow soybeans — the sort the U.S. grows in abundance — including 25 percent in June and 5 per cent on September 1, bringing the current tariff level to 33 per cent. If the additional tariffs are removed, tariffs on U.S. soybeans would return to 3 percent — the same rate paid by importers of Brazilian soybeans, which have largely filled the gap left by the U.S (Xin, 2019. Para.12).
\
Reference
\ Xin, Z. (2019). China to exempt U.S. pork and soybeans from additional trade war duties, in response to Trump’s tariff delay. South China Morning Post. September 13, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/13/china-trump-trade-war-tariff-delay-1494507 \
China's December soybean imports surge on year as cargoes clear customs.
\
Gu and Singh (2020) January 13, stated that:
\
BEIJING (Reuters) - China’s soybean imports in December surged 67% from a year earlier to a 19-month-high, customs data showed on Tuesday, as a flurry of U.S. and Brazilian cargoes booked earlier cleared customs (Para. 1). China traditionally sources U.S. soybeans in the fourth quarter of the year when U.S. produce dominates the market. But American cargoes plunged after Beijing slapped hefty tariffs in 2018 on a list of U.S. goods including soybeans in a tit-for-tat trade war (Para. 9). Chinese importers later resumed purchases of U.S. beans during a truce in the trade war and after Beijing issued extra tariff-free waivers for some American shipments. China customs vice minister Zou Zhiwu noted on Tuesday that soybean and pork imports had rebounded significantly in December. China and the United States have agreed an initial, or Phase 1, trade deal, which is expected to be signed on Jan. 15. U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Sunday he expected China to buy $40 billion to $50 billion of agricultural products under the deal. Analysts expect that soybeans, China’s biggest agricultural import from the United States, would make up a big part of any such purchases ((Para. 9-13).
\ Gu, H. & Singh, S. (2020). China's December soybean imports surge on year as cargoes clear customs. Reuters. Business News. January 13, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-trade-soybeans/chinas-december-soybean-imports-surge-on-year-as-cargoes-clear-customs-idUSKBN1ZD0C2

Further reducing my forecast from 27% Yes to 9% Yes.  My previous forecast rationale: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/934917 My updated forecast is based on the following: 1) The Phase 1 deal announcement seems like an interim ceasefire on tariffs and a ‘wait and see’ until after the November 2020 election: China didn’t commit to specific tariff reductions under the agreement but instead has vowed to exempt certain U.S. products from its duties in order to meet the purchasing targets laid out in the deal. Trump administration has no current plans to lift the more than $360 billion worth of tariffs it has levied against China since 2018 despite the Phase 1 agreement. There are no other oral agreements between US and China for a future reduction in tariffs. The joint statement, first given to Bloomberg reported that tariffs wouldn’t be removed before the presidential election in November 2020. 2) Even the talks leading up to the Phase 1 deal were said, at the time, by some to have been hyped up (SCMP Dec 27th 2019): “While the so-called phase one trade deal was largely viewed as face-saving optics in a time of crisis, experts agreed it was far from enough to end the protracted trade war, dissolve deep-running tensions or undo the damage caused to both countries and the global economy.” SCMP Dec 27th 2019. 3) US soybean harvest season has largely passed: As @Ikresnak and others have mentioned in previous comments, “Harvest season in the US is largely passed, but the end of this question coincides with South Americas harvest season.” China knows it has a weakness in too much reliance on the US, so they will continue to find other sources to reduce their reliance on the US soybean market. One reason why China could reduce or remove tariffs on US soybeans before 1 May 2020 is because of the pressure Trump may feel in an election year to get a deal, however, after the Phase 1 agreement announced Jan 15, 2020, this is looking significantly less likely - especially before 1 May 2020. 4) Difference between goodwill gesture and a concession:  Both Trump and Xi have said that the tariff exemptions and waivers that they gave to each other in 2019 (apparently because they acknowledged that both economies were hurting) were goodwill gestures and not a concession. I’m not sure about Trump, but China doesn't seem the country to concede - they won’t want to lose face. "The biggest thing is not to appear to be capitulating to the US" said Yun Jiang, a Chinese policy analyst. So one shouldn’t overreact to a goodwill gesture by viewing it a sign that tariff reductions or removals will take place shortly after. 5) China has previously demanded “complete removal" of tariffs: China has demanded the “complete removal" of tariffs. It's not known if this is a mandatory/non-negotiable prerequisite from China, but apparently Trump says China's request for "complete removal" is a non-starter for the US in trade negotiations. On Friday, November 8, US President Donald Trump told reporters, “China would like to get somewhat of a rollback, not a complete rollback because they know I won’t do it.” What happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object? This is what makes me think that it's less likely that a significant trade accord will get signed any time soon, let alone the reduction or removal of contentious US soybean tariffs before 1 May 2020. 6) During negotiations and prep for Phase 1, China was said to be reviewing tariff “exemptions” (not “reductions” or “removals”): Prior to the Phase 1 deal, a government source said that China was "reviewing tariff exemptions on $60 billion worth of US goods". Note that it didn't say reviewing tariff "reductions" or tariff "removals" 7) Buying more US agricultural products doesn't automatically necessitate that tariffs will be reduced or removed, especially when China may not need to remove or reduce soybean tariffs because the Chinese government can circumnavigate them using other means: Although it is reasonable to expect that China might reduce or remove tariffs on the basis of an agreement to buy more US agricultural products, it still doesn't guarantee that soybeans will be included among the "US agricultural products" that are being mentioned in this Phase 1 deal. Nor does it guarantee that tariff reductions or removals will happen before 1 May 2020. China may not need to reduce or remove tariffs in order to buy more agricultural products because they can, and have been, importing the soybeans on behalf of the private companies (i.e. the government does the buying and sells the soybeans onto the end-user). So essentially the government is using state-owned firms to buy soybeans that are exempt from the tariffs and in doing so they are circumnavigating the tariffs that private companies would otherwise be obliged to pay. 8) "China is using its tariff on US soybean as a weapon in the trade war" (Forbes 2019): Considering the fact that government entities can avoid their own duties, US soybeans are not priced out of the market. Rather, it’s more likely China is using soy as a weapon in its trade war arsenal and will continue to do so as long as tariffs are in place (Forbes, May 2019). 9) China is likely to keep the Soybean card for negotiation later: As @pofto alluded to in an earlier comment; since China has imposed other tariffs on US imported goods as part of the Trade War, it’s reasonable to see how these other tariffs would be removed or reduced well before China plays there biggest card and reduced or removes tariffs on US soybeans, especially before the 1 May 2020 deadline of this question. Yao Xinchao, professor of international trade at the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing was quoted saying "Pork and soybeans are two important bargaining chips that China won't play easily".  10) Tax exemptions and waivers are more likely: It has become increasingly likely that China will handle the trade war with Trump through a tax exemption or waivers, which are excluded from the resolution of the question. A Bloomberg article on Dec 24th 2019 mentioned: "China will provide retaliatory tariff waivers to buyers of U.S. farm products on a more regular basis after the countries reached a phase one trade deal, according to people familiar with the situation. Waivers had previously been given in tranches but they’ll now be handed out more frequently. The move will make it less punitive for Chinese companies to purchase U.S. goods that are still subject to retaliatory trade tariffs and thereby help Beijing meet any commitments it has made as part of a trade deal." 11) There is an argument that the reason why China won’t reduce or remove US soybean tariffs anytime soon is that it’s politically motivated: Sources say that China is being strategic with its retaliatory tariffs, targeting industries in states which President Trump won in 2016, making it more politically difficult for the President to continue his trade war. China knows that this represents a point of leverage: the trade war is playing out in the American heartland ahead of an election year. According to Forbes, a Chinese government official said: "It’s like election meddling". Some say China is betting on two Democratic Party candidates to be in their corner; Joe Biden and Kamala Harris are considered pro-Wall Street on China. A Biden or Harris victory might be great news for China, but some say that they are the only bet within the current crop of top 5 Democratic Party candidates that would be seen as a return to status quo trade relations. Farmers might bet that way too. For these reasons, I’m even less sure that China will reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans before 1 May 2020.

The text of the agreement contains no commitment to remove or lower tariffs, and in fact uses the word "tariff" only twice! It just says China will buy $12.5b in 2020 and 19.5b in 2021 in agricultural goods over and above the 2017 level (not $40b in additional agricultural goods, the number that is getting thrown around but seems to have no basis in fact). I think that China will not lower tariffs, and will just use TRQs to allow imports to hit their purchase quotas. IE what I've been saying the whole time. From Reuters:
"Soybean futures, which traded 0.4% lower throughout much of the deal signing ceremony, sank even further after Liu’s remarks, a sign that farmers and traders were dubious about the purchase goals. The deal doesn’t end retaliatory tariffs on American farm exports, makes farmers “increasingly reliant” on Chinese state-controlled purchases, and doesn’t address “big structural changes,” Michelle Erickson-Jones, a wheat farmer and spokeswoman for Farmers for Free Trade, said in a statement. " (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china/u-s-china-tiptoe-around-holes-in-new-trade-agreement-idUSKBN1ZE0I1?il=0) From Vox, note the final sentence:
"As for the United States, it canceled additional tariffs on about $160 billion of Chinese goods that were originally slated to go into effect in December 2019. It will also cut in half tariffs on $110 billion in goods introduced in September — but keep existing 25 percent tariffs on $250 in Chinese products. So duties will remain on some $360 billion in Chinese goods. Chinese retaliatory tariffs on $100 billion in US products will also stay in place. "
Changing forecast as there is no real agreement concerning yellow soya beans.

The Phase One deal did not include tariff reductions.  “There are no other oral or written agreements between the United States and China on these matters, and there is no agreement for future reduction in tariffs. Any rumors to the contrary are categorically false,” they said.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-tariffs/u-s-china-have-no-agreement-for-future-tariff-reductions-lighthizer-mnuchin-idUSKBN1ZD2PK

Coming down since the phase 1 deal did not include commitments. I don’t think there will be major developments between now and Phase II. That being said, I think there is still a risk of the Trump administration requiring Chinese tariff reductions being needed to start Phase II negotiations
Coming down markedly. Agreement to purchase more <> reduce/remove tariffs.

Phase One of the trade deal was just signed today, so there is hope that Phase Two would be signed before 1 May and that may remove the subject tariffs, however without details of the agreement, this is not a certainty as of yet (https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/news/world-policy/article/2019/12/13/phase-one-us-china-agreement-large). With the upcoming election, there is some US pressure to resolve the trade dispute, thus I've assigned a greater than 50% chance. According to https://www.politico.com/news/2020/01/15/what-is-in-us-china-trade-deal-099399, phase one does not remove the tariffs, although China has agreed to buy yellow soybeans (and other products).

The decision not to include a quid pro quo reduction of Soybean tariffs in the phase one agreement has convinced me that China will only waive tariffs in the near term and keep this card for later "phase two" negotiations.  The Chinese could remove or reduce tariffs on the US, but large orders from last fall have already had tariffs waived and South American soybean crop will start peaking in late spring.  By retaining the tariff in place, it allows the Chinese to keep the soybean card in the deck for a longer term.   Not right now --
https://www.theadvertiser.com/story/news/2020/01/09/louisiana-iowa-soybean-farmers-fear-irreparable-damage-tariffs/2850823001/
Total U.S. soybean exports have declined 29% to $16.9 billion in 2019 since a $23.8-billion high in 2017, according to the Agriculture Department. Although China has committed to increase its agricultural purchases, the phase one agreement will not remove the 25% tariff on U.S. soy products, a top concern for soybean farmers. Unless -- 
Rosa Wang, a Shanghai-based analyst at agricultural research firm JCI China, said she was “quite confident” that China could meet US President Donald Trump’s demand to buy at least US$80 billion of farm goods over two years, but the government would need to reduce tariffs or issue waivers to make sure private buyers join state buyers in importing American farm products.
Wang forecast that China could buy US$18.6 billion worth of soybeans, which dwarfs the next highest commodities.... Probably a longer term resolution (lever in U.S. politics?)
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/01/15/trump-sign-china-trade-deal-details-remain-mystery/4434592002/
Trump has said talks will begin immediately for a broader agreement but that it probably would not be finalized until after the November election.

US to Lift China Currency Manipulator Tag Ahead of Trade Deal (Bloomberg)
President Trump’s administration plans to lift its designation of China as a currency manipulator, people familiar with the matter said. The Treasury Department will make the move in a semi-annual report, expected to be released soon, after being delayed as the U.S. and China finalize a “phase one” trade pact, the sources said. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in August first formally labeled China a currency-manipulator. That prompted authorities in Beijing to increase transparency around how they manage the yuan. Some of that data has provided support for Treasury’s view that the People’s Bank of China engages in competitive devaluations of its currency, the people said. The administration had at one point considered maintaining the label and instead announcing it would monitor the yuan with the possibility of lifting the designation in August of this year, according to the people.
——————-
COMMENT: Keeping the same for now. I’m not sure President Xi will be moved to tears by the magnanimous act of trust!
Back to level of first forecast - valued daily news to much.

Soybean is an important weapon in China's trade war with the U.S.   It is the top U.S. export to China, constituting about 60% of the US exports to China (1).  It is unlikely that China will give up this weapon before the ending of the trade war with the U.S. Tariffs play an important role in a free market economy as they encourage buyers to seek alternative cheaper (with no tariff) sources.  However China's economy is not completely free.  There is a strong state-controlled component to it.  The Chinese authoritarian government could easily reduce an import by just demanding it to happen, instead of imposing tariffs.  Imposing tariffs on US imports is just a simple way to show its tit for tat strategy.  Tariffs do not mean much as it can demand a reduction of an import (even though it may be cheaper) and/or has lots of tariff exemptions and waivers (as it is frequently done). It is unlikely that a tariff reduction or removal on soybeans will be in the Phase 1 agreement, which is rumored to be signed in the next few days.  It is likely that China will not abandon this important weapon until a final agreement on the trade war.  Therefore, for a "yes" resolution to this question, a final agreement has to be done before May 1, 2020.  I don't think there is enough time to do that.  Furthermore, while the Trump administration might be eager to make a deal before the election, China may be willing to wait after the election.   (1)  https://www.stlouisfed.org/publications/regional-economist/third-quarter-2018/closer-look-exports-china

When Trump declared that a [Phase One deal had been struck with China](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/10/17/trump-says-china-will-buy-billion-year-us-agriculture-thats-not-what-china-says/) in October he said that China would be buying $40 to $50 billion in U.S. agricultural products. However, no time frame has been given (is this over multiple years?) and the details for Phase One are still being hammered out. 
If China has stepped up its soybean purchases or if the market believes that it will there should have been a rebound in its price. Unfortunately, it seemed to peak right after Phase One was announced and has recently gone on a skid to under $9 per bushel.
President Trump claimed that he struck a [“phase one” trade deal with China](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/10/11/us-stocks-poised-big-bounce-expectations-grow-us-china-trade-deal/?tid=lk_inline_manual_2) on Friday and that the Chinese agreed to massive purchases of U.S. farm products. But nearly a week has passed, and China has not confirmed that critical piece of the agreement.
According to the White House, a key part of Trump’s initial deal is China’s commitment to buy $40 billion to $50 billion worth of U.S. agricultural products. But nothing was written on paper, and China’s Commerce Ministry would [not confirm that figure](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/17/china-says-us-must-cancel-new-tariffs-for-ultimate-trade-deal.html) Thursday, saying instead purchases would be made according to Chinese market needs.
As Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He stood face to face in the Oval Office on Friday, a reporter asked whether the agreement was for $40 billion to $50 billion in purchases every year. Trump turned to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and asked him to “define that, please.”
“It will scale up to an annual figure. Yes,” said Mnuchin, who later added it would hit that higher level “within the second year."
A spokeswoman for the U.S. trade representative said Thursday that China had committed to $40 billion to $50 billion a year, “scaling up over two years,” implying purchases would be significantly higher by 2021.
==========
China is picking up soybean cargoes in Brazil, dashing hopes for big American sales immediately after a partial trade deal is signed with the U.S. next week, according to people familiar with the matter.
Private buyers from China have purchased about 10 cargoes from the South American nation so far this week, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the deals are private. Most of the soybeans are for shipments from January through April, the people said.
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/china-purchases-brazilian-soybeans-trade-182419133.html

As White House plans U.S.-China Phase 1 ceremony, still no final deal text
*
Shalal and Mason (2020) January 10, stated that: * WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Trump administration has invited at least 200 people to a Jan. 15 ceremony to witness the signing of the Phase 1 trade deal between the United States and China, but the two nations have not yet finalized what, exactly, will be signed, White House officials said on Friday. On Dec. 15, United States Trade Representative (USTR) Robert Lighthizer said a deal to end the trade war between the world’s biggest importer and largest exporter was “totally done,” minus translation of an 86-page document into Chinese. White House officials said on Friday the translation still has not been completed, although White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow told Fox Business Network it “is virtually complete” and the signing is “all on schedule.” Officials are waiting “for the Chinese translation of the 86-page agreement,” White House adviser Peter Navarro told CNBC later. The deal is “in the bank,” he said. Top officials from Beijing and U.S. lawmakers from states affected by the 18-month trade war are expected to attend the signing in the White House’s East Room, between President Donald Trump and China’s vice premier Liu He, according to several sources (Para. 1-5).
*
Reference
* Shalal, A. & Mason, J. (2020). As White House plans U.S.-China Phase 1 ceremony, still no final deal text. Reuters. Business News. January 10, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china/as-white-house-plans-u-s-china-phase-1-ceremony-still-no-final-deal-text-idUSKBN1Z91VU
China will likely use exemptions and waivers to negotiate in short term.

China imports soybeans to feed its livestock, primarily swine. In 2019 significant number of swine were culled due to fever. Consequently the domestic demand for soybean has declined in China. China has also begun import of soybeans from Brazil and increased domestic production to meet the demand. Higher import tariff on US soybeans would not yield much revenue because of the reduced imports. Also higher tariffs would increase cost to domestic farmers already reeling under the impact of swine fever. A reduction in tariff is beneficial to China and would go a long way in appeasing Trump who has a substantial support base among US soy farmers. A reduction in tariff need not result in higher imports from US farmers though. So net gain would be China's favour. Hence I expect China to reduce tariff on US soybeans before May 2020.

For those just arriving, a good timeline from South China Morning Post: https://www.china-briefing.com/news/the-us-china-trade-war-a-timeline/ After everything I've read, I'm now pretty sure that China will handle this through an exemption, as they did for a half dozen chemicals back in Dec (see http://www.mof.gov.cn/zhengwuxinx/i/zhengcefabu/201912/t20191219_3444518.htm - CN only). Note that those exemptions are in force for 1 year, so expire Dec 26th 2020.  There's some hints at this in the recent language around the agreement eg see here "China will not increase its grain import quotas to meet demands from the United States"
https://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrapoza/2020/01/08/is-china-already-failing-to-meet-phase-one-trade-agreements/#142a11665f4c
"China will not increase its annual low-tariff import quotas for corn, wheat and rice to accommodate stepped-up purchases of farm goods from the United States, senior agriculture official Han Jun said on Tuesday, according to local media group Caixin."
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/09/chinas-vice-premier-liu-to-sign-us-trade-deal-in-washington-next-week.html Quotas for low-tariff/exempted imports only matter if the tariffs are still in place. The fact they are not even raising the quotas for corn etc does not bode well for the complete repeal of tariffs on soybeans and other. There was supposedly a 90 day exemption after Trump and Xi talked at G20 (https://soygrowers.com/key-issues-initiatives/key-issues/trade/)
They were also using tariff waivers up until Dec 3rd when they began to run out. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-12-03/china-exhausts-waivers-to-buy-u-s-soy-free-of-trade-tariffs) 
On Dec 6 there was news that they were exempting some soybeans and pork (https://www.bangkokpost.com/world/1810074/china-to-exempt-some-us-soybean-pork-from-tariffs), but again that seems to be piecemeal. (Also https://www.agricensus.com/Article/China-issues-fresh-US-soybean-quota-to-crushers-amid-trade-talks-9702.html)
They once again added tariff-reduced quota on Dec 23.
https://www.hellenicshippingnews.com/china-offers-tariff-free-quota-for-10-million-t-of-u-s-soybean-purchases-sources/ My guess is that they don't bother to lower or repeal the existing yellow soybean tariff, but that they leave them in place and retain a high degree of control over how much soy to import from USA via the use of exempted import quotas. If they were going to drop the tariff on soybeans, why not do it as one of the 859 items they cut tariffs for on Dec 23rd? (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-12-23/china-to-cut-tariffs-on-goods-including-pork-tech-items)  Soy is not on the list. (http://gss.mof.gov.cn/gzdt/zhengcefabu/201912/P020191220564315355326.pdf - CN only)

"Remove" or "Reduce" - infers to me that a considered go-forward on trade relations with the US would have been decided upon - of which this would be a noteworthy foundational plank. 
I don;t see that happening in 120 days.
I feel instead the Chinese will wait out the election before engaging in such a such strategic-level trade re-assessment.

I'm not sure there's much information available to estimate a base rate probability for this one, but the longer we get into the question period without reduction or removal, the lower the probability of it happening in the remaining, diminishing timeframe. I'll start at 50/50 and then look at lowering over time.

Trump trade adviser Navarro says the China phase-one deal has 'great stuff in it,' and he sees the Dow soaring to 32,000 Mohamed (2020) Jan. 2, states that:

One of President Donald Trump's top trade advisers says that a "great" phase-one trade deal with China is a certainty and that he expects both the US economy and the stock market to surge in 2020.
"It's got great stuff in it," Peter Navarro told CNBC on Tuesday of the trade deal. "It's got essentially the same chapter we had in the May deal that the Chinese walked away from on intellectual-property theft. So that's a good deal."
"That one's in the bank," he said in response to questions about the pact. Navarro's comments came before Trump tweeted that he would sign the so-called phase-one trade deal with China on January 15 and planned to travel to Beijing to begin the next round of talks.
Markets on Thursday jumped on trader optimism that they could soon see an end to the trade war and the potential removal of tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars in worth of products. "We're just waiting for the Chinese translation of the 86-page agreement, and I'm trying to figure out whether it's going to be more pages or less in Chinese," Navarro said. He declined to comment to CNBC on Trump's tweet about the meetings later this month (Para. 1-5).
*
Reference
*
Mohamed, T. (2020).  Trump trade adviser Navarro says the China phase-one deal has 'great stuff in it,' and he sees the Dow soaring to 32,000. Markets Insider. News. Jan. 2, 2020. Retrieved from
https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/peter-navarro-trump-china-phase-1-trade-deal-great-stuff-dow-to-jump-1028791101

My impression of trade talk process is that the Chinese delegation is running through a series of actions that lift expectations/sparking speculation followed by deflating news and delays. Soybean farmers being the most distressed may be pawns here. gradually dropping over time till I hear here in the Delta that China Origin orders are being placed.

Chinese soybean orders increased following speculation of, then conclusion of a "phase one" trade agreement.  This development does not necessarily mean China will reduce or remove the tariff's currently levied on soybean imports.  In early December the Chinese demonstrated a willingness to waive the tariff, but removal is another step and another chess piece in ongoing trade negotiations.  China's removal or reduction of tariffs will be part of the larger trade negotiations rather just a soybean supply and demand issue.  There is a crop timing aspect to consider for both countries and  According to a Reuters article on the Successful Farming website, the Chinese have eased regulations on soybean imports coming across their northern border with Kazakhstan and Russia.  Though neither of these countries can currently make up for the U.S. volume or the anticipated Chinese demand, it does signal an effort to expand their potential soybean trading partners over the long term (potential mitigation for leaving tariffs in place and granting waivers only).  Brazil has been the big winner in the current soybean market, increasing their exports to China over 2019.  The latest Chinese waivers have seen a slight shift back toward the U.S. and away from Brazil.  October through December is the prime harvest period for U.S. soybeans, while Brazil is planting soybeans during this period (http://www.soybeansandcorn.com/Brazil-Crop-Cycles).  An agreement to reduce or remove tariffs on US soybean would have a higher impact in Jan when the agreement is due to be signed.   According to multiple news sites, President trump will sign the agreement on 15 January.  The deal reportedly includes Chinese agreement to buy more U.S. Farm products, and according to some sites roll back the September tariffs.  According to Salvatore Babones writing for Foreign Policy, the phase one deal notes U.S. tariffs from September will be rolled back by half, but original tariffs will remain in force.   This provides a potential justification for rolling back at least one phase tariffs as a quid pro quo for U.S. changes.  Though none of the sources noted thus far include a specific change to the Chinese soybean tariff, it is a logical inclusion.  The timing of the agreement, the increased orders, and the timing of the northern hemisphere crop sales all point to at least some changes in the tariff structure.
Raising forecast but still maintain low level of confidence in the capability of the US and China delegations agreeing.

China's November soybean imports rise after US trade deal Kunk, Wiseman and McDonald (2019). Dec 26, stated that: OMAHA — President Donald Trump likes to joke that America's farmers have a nice problem on their hands: They're going to need bigger tractors to keep up with surging Chinese demand for their soybeans and other agricultural goods under a preliminary deal between the world's two largest economies (Para. 1). The so-called Phase 1 deal that the two sides announced Dec. 13 did manage to de-escalate the standoff and offer at least a respite to American farmers. Yet the truce put off for future negotiations the toughest and most complex issue at the heart of the trade war: The Trump administration's assertion that Beijing cheats in its drive to achieve global supremacy in such advanced technologies as driver-less cars and artificial intelligence (Para. 9). The administration says — and independent analysts generally agree — that China steals technology, forces foreign companies to hand over trade secrets, unfairly subsidizes its own firms and throws up bureaucratic hurdles for foreign rivals. Beijing has rejected the accusations and contended that the administration is instead trying to suppress a rising competitor in international trade. Under the preliminary U.S.-China deal, Trump suspended his plan to impose new tariffs and reduced some existing taxes on Chinese imports. In return, Lighthizer said, China agreed to buy $40 billion a year in U.S. farm exports over two years, among other things. (Beijing also committed to ending its long-standing practice of pressuring foreign companies to hand over their technology as a condition of gaining access to the Chinese market (Para. 9- 11)).
*
Reference
* Kunk, J., Wiseman, P. & McDonald, J. (2019). China's November soybean imports rise after US trade deal. Herald & Review. Dec 26, 2019. Retrieved from
https://herald-review.com/business/agriculture/china-s-november-soybean-imports-rise-after-us-trade-deal/article_1268c3ec-f6e8-50da-aab8-313a861e7995.html

Dehlinger, K. (2019). China, US Announce Trade Deal. Progressive Farmer. World & Policy. December 13, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.dtnpf.com/agriculture/web/ag/news/world-policy/article/2019/12/13/phase-one-us-china-agreement-large Huang, C. (2019). The US and China have a trade deal, but only Washington has what it wants. The South China Morning Post. This Week in Asia. Dec, 22, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3042819/us-and-china-have-trade-deal-only-washington-has-what-it-wants * Alper, A. (2019). Trump says trade deal with China to be signed 'very shortly'. Reuters. World News. Dec 21, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-trade/trump-says-trade-deal-with-china-to-be-signed-very-shortly-idUSKBN1YP0MK * Agreement Between th3e United States of America and the People’s Republic of China. December 13, 2019. Fact Sheet https://ustr.gov/sites/default/files/US-China-Agreement-Fact-Sheet.pdf * Information on specific chapters of the Phase One agreement is provided below:
• Agriculture: The Agriculture Chapter addresses structural barriers to trade and will
support a dramatic expansion of U.S. food, agriculture and seafood product exports,
increasing American farm and fishery income, generating more rural economic activity,
and promoting job growth. A multitude of non-tariff barriers to U.S. agriculture and
seafood products are addressed, including for meat, poultry, seafood, rice, dairy, infant
formula, horticultural products, animal feed and feed additives, pet food, and products of
agriculture biotechnology.
I'm not expecting China and the US to be in full agreement as to the shape and form of the trade negotiations concerning the purchase of agricultural products.

My forecast remains unchanged @ 27% Yes Perhaps I've got this wrong, as the majority of forecasters here, at the time of updating, think the probability is on average 80% Yes. My unchanged update is mainly due to the fourth (4th) commandment: "Strike the right balance between under- and overreacting to evidence". I may have underreacted in light of the new phase one deal, but here's my rationale: 1. The question clearly states that: "Tariff exemptions and waivers would not count toward the resolution of the question." China has declined to disclose details of the scale of tariff reduction and about what they have agreed as part of Phase 1. So far, only the US has announced that the US has agreed to cancel the planned December tariffs and reduce some of their existing tariffs on the basis that China will "buy more US agriculture products" but there has been no suggestion of "tariff reductions" from China in return. Recently, waivers/exemptions have been issued by China that allows for another 2 million tonnes in purchases without the extra tariffs. But, again, these are not tariff reductions. Additionally, China's act to "exempt certain products" (which China said was designed to ease the dispute's impact on American companies) does not offer relief from tariffs on the big-ticket agricultural products such as soybeans and corn that are causing the most hurt in the US. "Pork and soybeans are two important bargaining chips that China won't play easily" said  Yao Xinchao, professor of international trade at the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing.  2. Trump is demanding that China buys 50 billion worth of agriculture products "pretty soon". China will not be rushing into anything any time soon. It could be very difficult for China to buy this amount given the current circumstances. These targets are difficult and China will be very careful not to commit to anything because it could put China into a difficult position with existing trade partners. It's more likely that the purchases of US agricultural products will be decided by market prices. Even if China agrees to try and buy the amount of US agricultural products that Trump wants China to buy, China is still unlikely to commit to reducing or removing tariffs - imposed specifically on U.S. yellow soybeans - unless they can be very sure it will be beneficial for them to do so. China knows that Trump could simply reimpose tariffs on a whim and then China would be stuck with large purchases or contracts with US suppliers and their products. Instead, China is saying that any deal "needs to be mutually beneficial", hence China's concerns about rushing in to sign anything too quickly. Trump recently said it was possible an agreement might not be reached until after the election in November 2020, while the Chinese foreign ministry said Beijing did not have a deadline for reaching a deal. For the above reasons, I forecast that, based on current evidence, it is still unlikely that China will reduce or remove any tariffs imposed on U.S. yellow soybeans before 1 May 2020.

Latest news indicate considerable progress (at least in rhetoric - again) towards a Phase 1 agreement [1]. Swanson, Rappeport and Bradsher (2019) Dec. 12, stated that: WASHINGTON — The United States has settled on final terms of a partial trade deal with China, several people familiar with the negotiations said, a development that could ease tensions between the world’s largest economies just days before the long-running trade war is set to escalate. President Trump met with his top economic advisers Thursday afternoon at the White House, where the president agreed to significant reductions on tariffs he has placed on $360 billion of Chinese goods in return for China’s commitment to purchase American farm products and make other concessions, the people said. As part of the agreement, the president is expected to announce that he will delay or cancel tariffs on $160 billion of consumer products from China that are scheduled to go into effect on Sunday. Those additional tariffs would have resulted in the United States taxing nearly everything China ships into the United States and foregoing them would prevent another escalation in a trade fight that has inflicted economic damage on both sides of the Pacific (Para. 1-3). Swanson, A., Rappeport A. & Bradsher, K. (2019). U.S. Settles on Outline of Elusive Trade Deal. The New York Times. Economy. Dec. 12, 2019

A permanent reduction/removal of tariffs depends at least on a so-called Phase 1 agreement [1, 2, 3, 4, 8]. Thus, the first issue that arises is if there will be a Phase 1 agreement. This does not seem far fetched from a rational point of view. Both parties have an interest in coming to an agreement, in particular the Republican-led US side that hopes to rely upon positive news about the economy for the next election campaign - regardless of the current rhetoric [5]. Therefore, the pressure on the US negotiators will rise continuously - at least up to the point Republicans rely upon economic successes as main reelection argument. If a possible agreement does not satisfy US demands, they could also focus on the argument they used to legitimize the trade dispute in the first place: China as malicious actor and threat to the US. The second issue that arises is if there will be a Phase 1 agreement before 1 May 2020. In general, there have already been several annoucements indicating an agreement is close to completion [7]. However, the absence of an agreement indicates that there are still major technical issues to be sorted out [8] (- or issues of political strategy?). As it is the main challenge for both sides to not loose face in an agreement, neither can accept a result that strongly hurt their legitimacy domestically. That said, China may accept that it cannot win the trade war [9, 11] - or whatever you may call a result in the end [10]. While the pressure seems to increase more on the US side as the election approaches, China can neither move as far away from its core positions the US would like them to do nor allow themselves to insist on a position that would be perceived as a US defeat by the US public. Otherwise, Trump may indeed follow through with his current rhetoric of not needing an agreement in 2020 [5,6]. If the new tariffs kick in December 15, 2019 or are postponed may be a sign in what direction the talks are going in the coming months. All in all, I assume there will be a Phase 1 agreement and it's likely to consist of the reduction or even removal of tariffs on US soybeans but I'm pessimistic that it will be implemented before 1 May 2020. It may, however, be the case that the time frame to come to an agreement will have already been forfeited by then. Let's see if the new tariffs kick in on Sunday or not. Chinese-US relations have not gotten better and continued tariffs enable Chinese strength vs American weakness. Without substantial American concessions, which I believe are unlikely as the hard line approach has been a rallying cry for the US President and associated Republicans, there's little likelihood of any tariff decreases on such a visible commodity. Not to mention the US subsidies for American Farmers impacted by the trade war.
Counting on some rapprochement between US and China within this timeline. Both need each other more than they’d like. Uncle Xi and Trump could both claim (and need) a measure of normalcy.
Markets will tighten as US output comes in reduced from expectations due to rain that delayed both planting and harvesting. Drying costs higher. China cant afford to tariff incoming foodstuffs.

Half of the "negotiators" don't understand what they're doing, and there isn't a loud enough push back from the American public to make the president reconsider his actions, so no progress is going to be made.

As others have observed, China is diversifying away from US.  Less need to change tariffs.

China gets massive amounts of soybeans from Brazil and Argentina as well as (historically the US). Harvest season in the US is largely passed, but the end of this question coincides with South Americas harvest season. https://www.thebalance.com/soybean-planting-and-harvest-seasons-809258 I think this represents a larger macro trend of diversification away from US based agriculture supply chains in China. Therefore, if continued trade tensions are the base case I don’t think the US will give up its leverage and China will continue to find other sources. A significant trade resolution (addressing some or all structural issues) is needed for the US to lift soybean tariffs in my opinion. The only reason I’m not closer to 5-15% on this question is the pressure Trump may feel in an election year to get a deal
